node.statement: Step 1.4.2 (Structural analogy: Boulatov GFT and BLM diagrams): The Boulatov group field theory (Boulatov 1992, Freidel 2005) is a field theory of a scalar field phi(g1,g2,g3) on SU(2)^3, invariant under diagonal SU(2) action, with a tetrahedral interaction vertex. Its key property: each Feynman diagram Gamma of the Boulatov model is dual to a triangulation T_Gamma of a 3-dimensional simplicial complex, and the Feynman amplitude A(Gamma) equals the Ponzano-Regge amplitude of T_Gamma. When SU(2) is replaced by the quantum group U_q(su(2)) at q = exp(2*pi*i/r), the Feynman amplitudes become exactly the Turaev-Viro amplitudes of the dual triangulations. The BLM model shares the algebraic building blocks (quantum 3j symbols at the vertex, quantum 6j symbols in non-melonic diagrams) but differs structurally from the Boulatov model in three ways: (1) BLM uses a SINGLE fixed spin j (odd integer), while Boulatov/TV sums over ALL admissible spins; (2) BLM is a 0+1 dimensional quantum mechanics with a fixed finite number N = 2j+1 of fermionic modes, while Boulatov is a field theory on a group manifold generating arbitrary triangulations; (3) BLM diagrams arise from a specific Hamiltonian H_q = {Q_q, Q_q^dagger} on a Fock space, while Boulatov diagrams arise from a partition function integral. Consequence: individual BLM non-melonic Feynman diagrams (tetrahedron involving {6j}_q, cube involving {12j}_q, etc.) evaluate to the SAME quantum recoupling symbols that appear as TV weights, but the BLM Feynman expansion does NOT produce a sum over triangulations of 3-manifolds. The map from the full BLM diagram expansion to TV-type topological invariants remains an open problem.
